channel.title: Need Help with reading from files
channel.description:
I was wondering if anyone here could tell me how to simpley have a class that reads from a .txt file and puts the contents into a variable based on a number in front of that line.
EXAMPLE---
1 How are you? 2 This is dumb! 3 I hate you... 4 Moo?
If it would be easier, or more possible, then I could use a deliminator such as *. I don't really care, I would just like to know how this would work. Thanks :D
MSN-PRchris47@aol.com or Chris@limitedAnimation.net AIM-PRchris47

normally a method gets deprecated because there is a better method that does the same thing made

item.title: Need Help with reading from files
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.DataInputStream;
import java.io.IOException;

/**
* @author TeleNubby
*/
class FileReader
{
       public static void main(String[] args)
       {
              //We will use this to store each line in. Temporary field.
              String tempData;
              try
              {
                     //We use this because it has the readLine() method. Ideal for text documents.
                     DataInputStream inStream = new DataInputStream(new FileInputStream("file.txt"));

                     //Loop through each line in the document and save the line to variable tempData.
                     while((tempData = inStream.readLine()) != null)
                     {
                            //We can now process the line in any way we want to.
                            System.out.println(tempData);
                     }
              }
              catch(Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
       }
}

Just a warning though, the method readLine() in the java.io.DataInputStream class is deprecated. This means it can be excluded from any future JDK update without warning. So use it at your own risk. It’s not much of a big deal, but its all good. If you care a lot about deprecated methods, try using the java.io.BufferedReader class. I just happened to use this one as it can be used for much more than just reading a file line by line.

Read full topic

import java.util.*;
import java.io.*;
public class FileReader
{
  public static void main(String args[])
  {
    Scanner fileIn = new Scanner(new File("folder/file.txt"));

    //your code, I would assume using String class and array for each line..
    //out would look something like System.out.println(i + " lines[i]");

    fileIn.close(); // close the file
  }
}

TextReader tr = new StreamReader("\\test.txt");     

            int NumberOfLines = 15;         

            string[] ListLines = new string[NumberOfLines];           

            for (int i = 1; i < NumberOfLines; i++)
            {
                ListLines[i] = tr.ReadLine();
            }

            Console.ReadLine();
            tr.Close();
using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Text;
using System.IO;

[/quote]
What the fuck, are you serious?[/quote]
Oops, i didn’t even write it, in a google search i got this:

item.title: Need Help with reading from files
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

import java.io.BufferedInputStream;
import java.io.DataInputStream;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.FileNotFoundException;
import java.io.IOException;

/**
 * This program reads a text file line by line and print to the console. It uses
 * FileOutputStream to read the file.
 * 
 */
public class FileInput {

  public static void main(String[] args) {

    File file = new File("C:\\MyFile.txt");
    FileInputStream fis = null;
    BufferedInputStream bis = null;
    DataInputStream dis = null;

    try {
      fis = new FileInputStream(file);

      // Here BufferedInputStream is added for fast reading.
      bis = new BufferedInputStream(fis);
      dis = new DataInputStream(bis);

      // dis.available() returns 0 if the file does not have more lines.
      while (dis.available() != 0) {

      // this statement reads the line from the file and print it to
        // the console.
        System.out.println(dis.readLine());
      }

      // dispose all the resources after using them.
      fis.close();
      bis.close();
      dis.close();

    } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    } catch (IOException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

I didnt write this but it may help.

Read full topic
